Literature Review: Plant hormones, or phytohormones, are pivotal signaling molecules that orchestrate plant growth, development, and responses to environmental stimuli. These molecules, including auxin (IAA), abscisic acid (ABA), cytokinin (CK), gibberellin (GA), ethylene, and jasmonic acid (JA), are synthesized in minute quantities but exert profound effects on plant physiology. The regulation of hormone homeostasis is a complex process involving biosynthesis, catabolism, perception, and transduction. A critical aspect of this regulation is the transport and localization of hormones, which ensures their distribution to target sites where they can exert their effects. This literature review delves into the mechanisms of plant hormone transport, focusing on the roles of transporters in establishing hormone maxima, gradients, and cellular and subcellular sinks, as well as their implications for plant development and stress responses. Auxin, primarily indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), is a key regulator of plant growth and development. Its polar transport, mediated by PIN-FORMED (PIN) and AUXIN1/LIKE AUX1 (AUX/LAX) transporters, is essential for establishing concentration gradients that direct processes such as organogenesis and tropic responses. Research by Petrášek et al. (2006) elucidated the role of PIN proteins in the directional transport of auxin, highlighting their importance in plant development. Similarly, the study by Swarup et al. (2001) on AUX1 demonstrated its critical function in auxin uptake, further underscoring the complexity of auxin transport mechanisms. Abscisic acid (ABA) plays a central role in plant responses to abiotic stress, particularly drought. The transport of ABA is facilitated by ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters and NITRATE TRANSPORTER 1/PEPTIDE TRANSPORTER FAMILY (NPF) proteins. Kang et al. (2010) identified ABCG25 as an ABA exporter, crucial for ABA-mediated stress responses. Additionally, Kanno et al. (2012) characterized NPF4.6 as an ABA importer, revealing the intricate network of ABA transport in stress signaling. Cytokinins (CKs) regulate cell division and differentiation, with their transport mediated by purine permeases (PUPs) and equilibrative nucleoside transporters (ENTs). Hirose et al. (2008) demonstrated the role of PUP1 in cytokinin uptake, highlighting its significance in cytokinin homeostasis. Similarly, the work by Sun et al. (2005) on ENT3 provided insights into the transport mechanisms of cytokinins, emphasizing their role in plant growth regulation. Gibberellins (GAs) are involved in various developmental processes, including seed germination and stem elongation. The transport of GAs is less understood, but recent studies have identified NPF3 as a GA transporter. Tal et al. (2016) showed that NPF3 facilitates GA movement, contributing to the regulation of plant growth and development. Ethylene, a gaseous hormone, influences fruit ripening and senescence. While ethylene itself is mobile, its precursor, 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC), is transported by LYSINE HISTIDINE TRANSPORTER 1 (LHT1). Shakeel et al. (2015) identified LHT1 as an ACC transporter, linking ethylene biosynthesis to its transport and function. Jasmonic acid (JA) is crucial for plant defense against herbivores and pathogens. The transport of JA and its precursors involves JASMONATE TRANSPORTER 1 (JAT1). The study by Li et al. (2017) on JAT1 revealed its role in JA transport, highlighting its importance in plant defense mechanisms. In conclusion, the transport and localization of plant hormones are fundamental to their function in plant growth, development, and stress responses. The identification and characterization of hormone transporters have provided valuable insights into the complex networks that regulate hormone homeostasis. Future research should focus on elucidating the regulatory mechanisms of these transporters and their interactions with other components of hormone signaling pathways, offering new avenues for enhancing plant resilience and productivity.
